summary: The Man With No Name (Clint Eastwood) enters the Mexican village of San Miguel in the midst of a power struggle among the three Rojo brothers (Antonio Prieto, Benny Reeves, Sieghardt Rupp) and sheriff John Baxter (Wolfgang Lukschy). When a regiment of Mexican soldiers bearing gold intended to pay for new weapons is waylaid by the Rojo brothers, the stranger inserts himself into the middle of the long-simmering battle, selling false information to both sides for his own benefit.

reviews.content: I was bored when I watched this the first time in a few parts, but then I gave it a rewatch and liked it a lot better. Clint Eastwood and his presence on the screen coupled with Ennio Morricone's brilliantly beautiful music is classic cinematic perfection. I feel like this had to be one of the most violent movies at the time it came out since Clint Eastwood got beat up and tortured so much in one scene, which takes guts to show in a Hollywood/American culture at a time when movies were supposed to be more pleasant and less risk-taking. This is one of the first westerns I've ever watched and it only got better from here!
Yee haw!  Yojimbo, Japanese film, remixed into an American western.  I'd pay a fistful of dollars to watch it in theaters ... maybe ;)

A Fistful of  Dollars is a true classic, that shaped the spaghetti western sub-genre in infinite ways. Beyond just being influential (though it was clearly influenced by another movie), it's just an entertaining action film.

An All Time Classic. The only real problem is the pacing which is good still but it takes its time with scenes and doesn't really have the epic scale of Leone's later works to justify it sometimes. This could've probably had 5-10 minutes cut off certain scenes. Besides that this is masterfully edited, acted, shot with an incredible music score. This film is full of mood and style. Ramon is an excellent menacing, ruthless and memorable villain. The story very much is very witty and is similar to that of The Sting. Anyone should give this a watch once.
One of the few perfect westerns
Cleverly written and incredibly directed, A Fistful of Dollars features an amazing score and a breakout turn from Clint Eastwood that marked a defining turn for Western movies.
Best of Movies/TV Series Collection

A Fistful of Dollars cleverly introduces us the complicated hierarchy and relations in a small western town, with its crafty but simple protagonist. This movie will always remain one of the most iconic westerns of all time.

This is a tough one. Some aspects of this movie are incredible but others are really weak. It averages out to an overall passable but forgettable experience.

By far the best part of this movie is the music. It's worth watching for the soundtrack alone. The costume and set designs are also really solid. Clint Eastwood's performance is charming and charismatic, making him hard not to root for.

However, the audio dubbing is TERRIBLE. Not just the dialogue, but all of the sound effects sound awkward and unrealistic. It's mostly this reason that the film has no sense of immersion. The voice acting is generally stiff as well. On top of that, the stunt acting is mostly mediocre but sometimes laughably bad. Finally, the fact that virtually the entire cast is Italian people in brownface doing awful Mexican accents made this film difficult to watch for me.

Also, the entire story relies on Clint Eastwood being basically infallible while everyone around him is a complete imbecile. There's no sense of tension; every scene ends with the protagonist either executing a ridiculous plan or just shooting everyone because he's apparently that good of a shot. None of the character motives are ever very clear.

It's culturally relevant and the music is bomb, but other than that it's objectively just not that good of a movie.

I liked the music featured - the famous score by Ennio Morricone, which certainly does add atmosphere and tension to the relevant scenes, as well as highlighting the isolated, somewhat desolate surroundings. Easwtood does, of course, play the very sly and laidback man with no name, although his character is referred to briefly as 'Joe'. Some scenes are rather slow paced and thus may put off some but the confrontation/fight scenes are, obviously, the opposite - there's a real frenetic energy which energised me while watching.

I liked that it has a more budget feel to it - that its clearly not a Hollywood film, featuring characters of different ethnicities/nationalities, the visually grainier feel to the shots and so on. Also the very bright red blood used didn't seem esp. realistic but I suppose there is a certain charm to that somehow.

I can understand the appeal of this film, its one of those whereby characters can say more in their moments of silence, via their facial expressions than by dialogue, so suffice to say I'd certainly recommend this film to fans of Westerns, more specifically Spaghetti Westerns (if you haven't seen it already).
a classical western tale
Hadn't see this one for decades.  Still holds up with Clint as the anti-hero who does good.  His good looks & swagger didn't hurt, either.

It's easy enough to buy into the praise heaped all over A Fistful of Dollars, but if you look at it objectively you might find that it's a decent movie, but maybe not the cinematic masterpiece that so many viewers claim.  The good?  It's the debut of Clint Eastwood's ‘Man With No Name' character, a steely-eyed killer with a clear moral compass.  The cinematography is generally excellent, giving a true feel for what it must have felt like in the Old West. As well, Ennio Morricone's score is catchy and effective.  The bad?  The dubbing is absolutely horrendous, and it's not helped at all by the wooden acting and corny dialogue.  The ugly?  The plot is often impossible to follow, implausible and ludicrous throughout.  Give it a watch but don't feel pressured by the hype into saying it's the greatest Western ever.  It's not.

I love this movie. It's a little on the shorter side, which plays to its benefit as an awesome badass Clint Eastwood cowboy adventure playing two families against each other for his own benefit. The only problems with the film is the lip syncing being poor due to it being filmed in Italy, I felt that the head family members of the Baxters, one of the families, are barely fleshed out (Idek their names), and besides Clint, and maybe Ramon and Silvanito, the rest of the supporting cast is very weak. Perfect soundtrack.
Like I say, anything Eastwood. And for you haters, go suck a duck.

This movie is criminally underrated. Yes, the inspiration from Kurosawa's own film is pretty easy to see, but it has Leone's own touch and stands on its own as a fantastic film. While it isn't quite as good as The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly and said Kurosawa film, it's still an example of masterful direction with a phenomenal script.

A Fistful of Dollars is not quite as good as The Good, The Bad and The Ugly from the Three Dollars trilogy(or Once Upon a Time in America and Once Upon a Time in the West), and I also think the film that inspired it Kurosawa's Yojimbo is the superior film. That said, that is not down-grading A Fistful of Dollars in any way, it is still a truly great film. As with all Leone's it is incredibly well made, the scenery is epic and looks gorgeous and the extreme close ups really helps to enhance the unrelenting violence. Ennio Morricone's score is wonderful with its minimalist style really fitting with the movie. The story is both elegiac which helps to give that feel of mystery to the Man with No Name's character and thrilling with the violence and the camera work. Leone's direction is as ever superb, as is the acting. Clint Eastwood became an international superstar and you can see why, he oozes charisma and his idea to make The Man with No Name mysterious with minimal dialogue proved to be a great one. Of the supporting cast, Gian Maria Volonte is especially impressive, as Ramon he snarls very convincingly. All in all, a great film. 9/10 Bethany Cox
For an old film I enjoyed and wasn't a bad Western...Clint Eastwood a great hero in this

Classic Western that launched the careers of Clint Eastwood and Sergio Leone.  Eastwood is superb as the lead, playing him as a man of few words but epic action (something that would become a trademark of many future Eastwood performances).  He gets great support from the rest of the cast, particularly Gian Maria Volonte as the villainous Ramon.  Behind the camera, Sergio Leone crafted a western that reset the genre, complete with anti-heroes and shady values (Eastwood's Joe is not exactly a pure hero).  It is matched by a nicely twisty plot along with some epic shootouts.  All in all, a classic western through and through, and Eastwood & Leone were just getting started.
The worst Spaghetti Western ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This simple, straight forward narrative offers no frills and would actually feel borderline parody if released today, largely because of just how often elements and tropes from this film can still be found in movies currently being released. (Which only seems fair since Leone apparently "borrowed" quite a bit from Kurosawa's Yojimbo)

It is hard to judge Eastwood in this role as he has become the universal mold used when assessing future Western protagonists. Would there be any point today to assess Michael Jordan's performance with the Bulls in the 1990s, since it is now basically unanimously agreed he is the best to ever play the game?

While Eastwood would likely be the MVP for most here, I'm giving it to Ennio Morricone whose score was instantly recognizable and somehow created a nostalgic feeling in me while watching a movie I had never seen.

Leone's first film of the Dollars trilogy set the standard for the successors, but stands out as an iconic film that helped shape westerns of any age that followed.

A supremely entertaining western from 1964!

I will say the dubbing nature of 'A Fistful of Dollars' is a little distracting early on, but by the time the opening portion concluded I was incredibly interested in what was happening onscreen. The pacing is excellent, thanks to some very fine cinematography, great action sequences and a top notch score.

Clint Westwood debuts as a leading movie star and is terrific throughout, portraying the wonderfully named J̶o̶e̶ "the Man with No Name". It's little surprise these are the films that truly made him. Away from Eastwood, I really enjoyed the trio that played the Rojo brothers - Gian Maria Volonté (aka Johnny Wels), Sieghardt Rupp and Antonio Prieto. They're just as important as the main man and play the roles superbly.

Having only fairly vague memories of Yojimbo, its still pretty clear how much of a copy of that film this is. I wouldn't hold that against it too harshly however. It's pretty entertaining but nothing in this for me to see it as truly great.

While not the best cowboy movie this film still boasts An impressive score by Ennio Morricone and A strong protagonist Clint Eastwood once again establishes himself as one of the biggest BadAsses in cinema history the final showdown is epic yet another great entry in the dollars trilogy

Sergio Leone's groundbreaking spaghetti western, this is the first of the 'man with no name' trilogy. Giving Clint Eastwood's character no real background or reason makes the film all the more exciting, and the loosely connected trilogy culminates in The Good The Bad and The Ugly (1966) one of the finest films ever to grace a screen. But this is where the idea was born.
Another sphagetti western that made Clint Eastwood a star!!!!!
Aside from the bad dubbing and one overlong sequence of people being gunned down, this film is nearly perfect and basically the greatest Western of all time.

I'm new to Leone. Recently watched Once Upon a Time in the West and was absolutely spellbound. That got me stoked to catch up on what I always hear celebrated as a classic, but good lord, Fistful of Dollars is tough to watch. It has its moments of humor and Clint Eastwood cool, but it has a paper-thin story and just way too much absurdity for me to overcome suspension of disbelief. There's very little tension or suspense, just ridiculous and repetitive montages of bloodless shootings with guys grabbing their backs and falling over. For the most part it's nicely shot, but the day-for-night  scenes and poor dubbing just makes it all seem farcical. It's weirdly paced and drags in a way that the significantly longer Once Upon A Time... does not.  In the latter, character and plot are slowly revealed in a way that keeps one invested. Here we have a nameless dude with a barely-hinted-at traumatic back story carrying the narrative weight, and I just didn't care. The Morricone score is iconic and might account for the indelible imprint this film has made on the culture, but it just feels like this is a case where the reputation far exceeds the reality. I kept looking for a way to watch it at 1.5x speed but I guess that's not an option on Amazon. I toughed it out till the end, hoping for redemption, but it just got stupider and stupider. Was this intended as a satire? It's so over the top and illogical that's the only reading that makes sense, but I think people do really take this seriously. I like silly genre films, but this one just feels tired and dated, no fun at all.

A total masterpiece, which does not suffer the weight of the years that have passed since its release. Even today it is possible to appreciate the innovations that the director has brought to the genre, bringing it freshness, offering entertainment to the viewer, despite being a "grown-up" genre.
Amazing western movie, love Clint Eastwood movies

Without comparing it to its sequels, A Fistful of Dollars is not exactly the most interesting movie about Clint Eastwood's Man With No Name character. While the beginning and end are very well done, the second act of the movie seems to really drag on.

This classic spaghetti western was very good. Clint Eastwood, Marianne Koch, Joe Egger, Gian Maria Volonte, and the rest of the cast did a spectacular job in this classic movie. The plot to the movie was thrilling, dramatic, and action-packed. It's about fighting for justice and getting it by any means necessary. If you haven't seen this classic western movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a definite must see.

"A fistful of dollars" is a very ironic name for this movie, as it was literally made for a very low amount of money, which is 200,000$. For such money and the release date, the movie is amazing. All the cliché we see in nowadays westerns are obviously ripped off from this movie. It is not as good as "The good, The bad and The ugly" or "For a Few Dollars More", but it sets the tone for the entire genre. The best part about this movie is Clint Eastwood and his coolness, nothing else. Pure 1 hour 40 minutes of him being awesome and pure testosterone! If you want to watch some classic with the feel of a muscular cowboy being oddly cool, then this movie is for you, but make sure you watch other parts of the trilogy too, if you don't like this one! They are also amazing! 
9/10, awesome character, awesome setting, respect for the job made for low budget and the announce date can't give me the opportunity to give this movie any less.

Sergio Leone directing, Clint Eastwood as lead, Gian Maria Volonté as Ramón, and  Ennio Morricone's soundtrack are all captivating. More engrossing than other westerns, you feel closer to the lead, brought in on his wit and cunning, and to the events, the whistling wind and Ramón's menace.

An unnamed stranger (Clint Eastwood) arrives at the little town of San Miguel, on the Mexico–United States border. Silvanito, the town's innkeeper, tells the Stranger about a feud between two smuggler families vying to gain control of the town: the Rojo brothers, Don Miguel, Esteban and Ramón (Gian Maria Volonté) and that of the town sheriff, John Baxter (Wolfgang Lukschy), his matriarchal wife Consuelo and their son Antonio. The Stranger decides to play each family against the other in order to make money, and proves his speed and accuracy with his gun to both sides by shooting with ease the four men who insulted him as he entered town. The Stranger seizes his opportunity when he sees the Rojos massacre a detachment of Mexican soldiers who were escorting a chest of gold that they had planned to exchange for a shipment of new rifles. He takes two of the dead bodies to a nearby cemetery and sells information to both sides, saying that two Mexican soldiers survived the attack. Both sides race to the cemetery; the Baxters to get the "survivors" to testify against the Rojos, and the Rojos to silence them. The factions engage in a gunfight, with Ramón managing to "kill" the "survivors" and Esteban capturing Antonio Baxter. While the Rojos and the Baxters are fighting, the Stranger searches the Rojo hacienda for the gold. While he is searching he accidentally knocks out a woman, Marisol. He takes her to the Baxters, who, in turn, arrange to return her to the Rojos in exchange for Antonio. During the exchange, Marisol's son, Jesús, runs towards her, followed by her husband, Julio. While the family embraces, Ramón orders one of his men, Rubio, to kill her husband as he has already told him to leave town. Silvanito attempts to protect the family with a shotgun with the Stranger backing him up. Neither Ramón nor any of his men attempt to challenge the Stranger, knowing that he is too fast on the draw...

Promoting "A Fistful of Dollars" was difficult, because no major distributor wanted to take a chance on a faux-Western and an unknown director. The film ended up being released in Italy on 12 September 1964, which was typically the worst month for sales. The film was shunned by the Italian critics, who gave it extremely negative reviews. Some American critics felt differently from their Italian counterparts, with Variety praising it as having "a James Bondian vigor and tongue-in-cheek approach that was sure to capture both sophisticates and average cinema patrons". Despite the negative reviews from Italian critics, at a grassroots level, its popularity spread and over the film's theatrical release, it grossed $4 million in Italy, about three billion lire, more than any other Italian film up to that point. The release of the film was delayed in the United States, because distributors feared being sued by Kurosawa. As a result, it was not shown in American cinemas until January 1967. Upon the film's American release in 1967, both Philip French and Bosley Crowther were unimpressed with the film itself. Critic Philip French of The Observer stated: "The calculated sadism of the film would be offensive were it not for the neutralising laughter aroused by the ludicrousness of the whole exercise. If one didn't know the actual provenance of the film, one would guess that it was a private movie made by a group of rich European Western fans at a dude ranch... A Fistful of Dollars looks awful, has a flat dead soundtrack, and is totally devoid of human feeling." Bosley Crowther of The New York Times treated the film not as pastiche, but as camp-parody, stating that nearly every Western cliche could be found in this "egregiously synthetic but engrossingly morbid, violent film". He went on to patronize Eastwood's performance, stating: "He is simply another fabrication of a personality, half cowboy and half gangster, going through the ritualistic postures and exercises of each... He is a morbid, amusing, campy fraud".

This classic Sergio Leone 1964 Spaghetti Western has all the trademarks from the director that started a whole new look and feel of the western genre. The film, an international co-production between Italy, West Germany, and Spain, was filmed on a low budget (reported to be $200,000), and Eastwood was paid $15,000 for his role. Released in Italy in 1964 and then in the United States in 1967, it initiated the popularity of the Spaghetti Western genre. It was followed by For a "Few Dollars More" and "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly", also starring Eastwood. Collectively, the films are known as the "Dollars Trilogy", or the "Man with No Name Trilogy". All three films were later released in sequence in the United States in 1967, catapulting Eastwood into stardom. The film has been identified as an unofficial remake of the Akira Kurosawa film Yojimbo (1961), which resulted in a successful lawsuit by Toho, Yojimbo's production company. "A Fistful of Dollars" was at first intended by Leone to reinvent the western genre in Italy. In his opinion, the American westerns of the mid- to late-1950s had become stagnant, overly preachy and not believable. Despite the fact that even Hollywood began to gear down production of such films, Leone knew that there was still a significant market in Europe for westerns. He observed that Italian audiences laughed at the stock conventions of both American westerns and the pastiche work of Italian directors working behind pseudonyms. His approach was to take the grammar of Italian film and to transpose it into a western setting. Clint Eastwood was instrumental in creating the Man with No Name's distinctive visual style as well. And Clint Eastwood truly personify the character with hardly any dialogue (which was Eastwood´s idea to cut down the dialogue) and I love the closeup structure in the film and the rotoscope title design. And adding to that we get beautiful visuals, great action and stand offs and proper western atmosphere. And Ennio Morricone´s soundtrack really sets the bar for how a western should sound like. 

Trivia: Clint Eastwood's trademark squint was caused by the combination of the sun and high-wattage arc lamps on the set. This has been described as the first "spaghetti western", but when this movie was made, there had already been about twenty-five such westerns produced in Italy. This was, however, the first to receive a major international release.

There is a before and after Clint Eastwood and Sergio Leone redefined westerns. This is a "must see" film which originated a new way of western movies, which Clint Eastwood continued back in the US with Outlaw Josey Wales and Pale Rider.

Most of what makes A Fistful of Dollars great is owed to Kurosawa, but it deserves credit for recognizing the themes present in the original work, their effective adaptation into a western setting, and the establishment of Eastwood's iconic Western persona. (4/5)

I expected more from this movie classic after reading other reviews, but the acting and dialogue was just too contrived to be taken seriously. It was entertaining but not very authentic even though the film was an innovative departure from the classic western where the good guy was more virtuous than Clint Eastwood's character, Joe.

While it's a very influential and pretty well-crafted film, it is derivative of a superior one (Yojimbo), and Toshiro Mifune is much more interesting character as the Samurai than Clint Eastwood is as the Man With No Name.

Sergio Leone directed this reworking of a classic of Japanese cinema, producing a really stunning movie. It seems almost unfair to call this a Spaghetti Western as that moniker has so many negative connotations but this is such a great example of the genre that it transcends the label. Clint Eastwood, in his first starring role, made his name with this and the two sequels and he really is fantastic as the enigmatic gunslinger who sets two rival outlaw families against each other for his own financial gains. He is electrifying in the role and set the standard for this kind of role. Leone's visual style and the stunning Ennio Morricone score produce a truly memorable cinematic experience which is a feast for all the senses.

A Fistful of Dollars defines the Spaghetti Western genre. I love the performance of Clint Eastwood, the setting of the town, the story, and the gun fights. Despite the movie has connections with Yojimbo, A Fistful of Dollars replaced samurai and swords with cowboys and guns. Without this movie, Western movies would never achieve success in the near future. Overall, The Man With No Name survived this review by a long shot.

A Fistful Of Dollars is not as good as later installments to the Dollars Trilogy but it still is a very good western.  It is full of iconic moments and Clint Eastwood is absolutely awesome as the man with no name.  A Fistful Of Dollars is a solid western that is worth a watch if you have not seen it.
A classic Clint Eastwood western.
Fabulous. One of those films I can watch over and over again. The Man With No Name makes his first on film appearance and it is perfection.
I don't know if as Italian I have to like "Spaghetti Western", but just for the soundtrack and for the direction, the movie deserve to be watched.
4th best western ever

The world's introduction to Clint Eastwood and Sergio Leone!

Director Sergio Leone splashes into the dirty desert world of Westerns with A Fistful of Dollars (1964). 

Leone clearly had a lower budget as the whole film takes place on one big town set alongside the surrounding mountains. The props look cheaper and the music repeats the theme a lot. The main theme is cool with a distinctive whistle whenever Clint Eastwood enters a scene. These are not complaints because you get to focus in on the action and dialogue instead of the background.  Leone makes the most of his little set by defining the Western film genre forevermore!

Unfortunately, the dubbing is bad for certain characters. There is an ungodly annoying boy whose dubber is too old and too obnoxious to have gotten the part, but I ignore him. Hearing Eastwood's natural voice is nice at least. The dubbing is the only real issue I have with A Fistful of Dollars and the delivery is still wonderful for a majority of the cast.

Leone's direction is killer from the get go as he introduces Eastwood with a legendary close-up of his face as Clint tilts his hat up to reveal his deadshot eyes. Leone captures a sense of dread in town with numerous warnings of death in this tale of gaining wealth, stealing money, saving families, rescuing women, and liberating a town. It's all classic hero tropes directed with Leone's lush style of gritty realism and sweat beaten brows.

Notably, A Fistful of Dollars was the first time most people saw Clint Eastwood act. He enters the Western genre young, handsome, and earnest. His acting is already iconic and mature here. Eastwood uses his intense piercing eyes to glare at his enemies, observe deadly situations, and build tension during a gun duel. He speaks with his unique gravel like voice out of the corner of his mouth for a cool and masculine effect. Eastwood makes you believe his nameless hero is an untouchable gunfighter from the first draw. Clint Eastwood is thoughtful, masculine, heroic, kindly, and cool as he defines the quiet Western hero from this point on within A Fistful of Dollars.

I must mention how cool his outfit is in A Fistful of Dollars. Clint Eastwood dons a cowboy hat, blue collared shirt, black jeans, wool jacket, and a killer poncho for the total Western hero fashion guide. All this complete with cowboy boots and spurs alongside Eastwood's gun holster and pistol. He looks cooler than literally any other Western hero as far as I'm concerned.

Marianne Koch is pretty as Marisol, a captive woman stolen from her husband and son. She doesn't do much, but when she looks at the screen or Eastwood, she entrances you immediately. You feel so sorry for her character just by a few looks of her sad eyes. Similarly, you feel awful for the matriarch of the Baxter family Consuelo Baxter, played by the mysterious and lovely Margarita Lozano.

Furthermore, Jose Calvo is awesome as the middle aged bar owner that befriends Clint. He is informative, funny, sweet, and cool as he helps Eastwood defend his home. Any time he is on screen, you are drawn to his warm character Silvanito. Likewise, I love the elderly undertaker Piripero, played by the giddy and delightful Joseph Egger, that also befriends Clint's nameless wanderer. They are the two best characters besides Clint's protagonist.

Gian Maria Volonte is outstanding as the cruel and devious Ramon Rojo. His villainous charisma is iconic as he kidnaps Marisol, murders dozens of men, and mercilessly beats on Clint Eastwood. You revel in the moment Clint bests him in their final quick draw duel. Leone directs their last encounter so perfectly. Volonte's shocked face seeing Clint alive, Clint appearing out of the smoke, Clint's metal plate trick, Clint's rapid fire pistol draw, and the pistol versus rifle debate. Leone was a master of directing and the last 15 minutes of A Fistful of Dollars is as genius as any sequence in any Western.
Classic Eastwood spaghetti western.
Not bad.  Plenty of violence and delightful villains.
all the 3 movies u have to see must !
Clint Eastwood plays the part of Joe so well
great score and directing

Great start to the "Dollars Trilogy" and homage(though uncredited at the time) to my favorite Kurosawa's film "Yojimbo". No one could play " The Man With No Name" but Eastwood who channeled Toshiro Mifune's Sanjuro.

The final duel is simply one of the tensest final scenes I've ever seen! But aside from it, the shootouts and gun fights are surprisingly boring, monotonous, and unvaried. One the other hand, the action and fight scenes that don't feature guns are so much fun, especially since Leone's style of camerawork and direction here are their best. I'm not exaggerating or anything; but A Fistful of Dollars really has some of the most inventive, and some of the coolest, camerawork and editing scenes I've seen in a Western film.

I haven't seen Kurosawa's Yojimbo yet; but I really liked the story of this film. It's a story full of surprises, and twist and turns that kept me quite engaged and engrossed most of the time. While the movie has its slow parts, and the plot doesn't evolve very smoothly; it gets messy and muddled halfway through, A Fistful of Dollars's story never loses its track. The movie also feels somewhat heavy-handed at times, largely because the dialogue gets clumsy and overly expository at moments.

I could have never imagined any actor who can be perfectly fit for this role as Clint Eastwood. He is as charismatic, bad-ass and tough as ever as the central character, Joe, and this was quite important, since this movie has this kind of story that focuses primarily on one protagonist (this is my favorite kind, btw).

Overall, Per un pugno di dollari is yet another great Leone Western that makes me excited to keep exploring his small but very solid filmography.

(8/10)

Blobbo never like this one. Thin plot, bad dubbing.

A movie that revolutionized the western genre, which still can be seen today. The technicolor is beautiful, the musical score is memorable and most of all, younger Clint Eastwood is unforgettable, he's just great. This is the role that projected him in the mainstream spotlight. Clint Eastwood was not director Sergio Leone's first choice for the 'Man with No Name' role, but he's excellent, and a huge part of why this film is successful.  He has the look of a rattlesnake in Leone's tight shots, exudes confidence and is tough, and yet he's also wryly playful.  His best lines occur early on, when he calls out four men for trying to intimidate him by shooting at his mule when he rode into town.  He says, "I don't think it's nice, you laughin'. You see, my mule don't like people laughing. He gets the crazy idea you're laughin' at him. Now if you apologize, like I know you're going to, I might convince him that you really didn't mean it."  It's easy to see why this film and the rest of the Spaghetti Western films which shortly followed established Eastwood as a star.  His poncho and thin black cigars are also iconic.

Leone's direction is also strong.  He creates a gritty, dark mood in this film, combines those tight shots on his actors with wide panoramas, and makes great use Ennio Morricone's music.  The film was shot in Spain and has some gorgeous shots early on, but I would have loved to have seen more of them.  The dialogue was clearly dubbed in afterwards, and except for Eastwood, is sometimes hard to understand.  José Calvo is good as the innkeeper who befriends Eastwood, but John Wells (Gian Maria Volontè) as the main villain is just average.  I was not happy that Leone had pirated Kurosawa's film Yojimbo (1961) to make this one, but tried to keep it out of my mind.  It's an entertaining movie, the birth of a great collaboration between Eastwood and Leone, and seems to have been influential to the entire genre, and for all that it's worth watching.

A Fistful of Dollars represents western cinema at it's most daring. When blood wasn't present in westerns, Leone introduced graphic violence instead of the standard "gun is pointed, fired, and the person it was aimed at would just fall." So many of Leone's mannerisms have become so incredibly famous that it is hard to recognize that it's all the result of one film. The traditional "western movie soundtrack" style originated from Ennio Morricone's beautiful and haunting work, the "silent bounty hunter" type character that is so prevalent in westerns originated from The Man With No Name, who speaks with his guns instead of his hands. This movie has no fluff. Everything is straight to the point, and the action is fast paced, but the fight scenes are long. Nothing feels out of place, with the exception of a few dubbed over voices for characters portrayed by non English speakers, but that goes to show that a multi-lingual cast can still play cohesively in a movie when it is put together by a master like Leone.
This is a movie that should not be missed by ANYONE.

I've watched Yojimbo (1961) many times but couldn't remember whether I'd seen this film from Sergio Leone's Man with No Name trilogy or not.  You can see why Kurosawa and co. successfully sued to get a part of the profits - Clint Eastwood effectively takes over the Toshiro Mifune character, albeit transplanted to the West (although Yojimbo clearly borrowed from the western genre too).  Of course, Eastwood brings his own unique iconography (lots of squinting) to the part just as Mifune had earlier (lots of scratching) - both were larger than life (and went on to play the same character in one or more sequels).  Leone uses the widescreen gloriously and the Spanish terrain is a good stand in for the Mexican setting.  The plot famously sees the Man/Samurai arriving in a lawless town and playing two rival gangs off against each other until both are dead and he can ride away with all of their money.  He's tough, cool, and in some ways more moral than the rest.  The bad get what's coming to them and the innocent and vulnerable are set free, all to the magnificent sounds of Ennio Morricone.  I still can't remember if I'd seen this before (or one or both of its sequels), so there is something about the blur of characters here (aside from Eastwood, of course, and Gian Maria Volontè as Ramon) that makes it difficult to stick.  For my money, I prefer Once Upon a Time in the West (1968) or Akira Kurosawa, for that matter.  Still, you can't deny the trailblazing effect of Leone's trilogy and Eastwood's dogged longevity.

A Fistful of Dollars is a fine western. The action sequences are great, the score is obviously memorable, and Clint Eastwood's grizzled performance is is considered iconic for a reason; that said, it's more than certainly the worst in its trilogy given the fact that the series' reputation and what the film actually delivers are so disparate. It feels extremely long at only 100 minutes (which is obviously inherent to the genre), with several superfluous sequences involving characters rambling off unnecessary exposition and a tedious back-and-forth narrative that takes far too long to corral the two competing families into the climactic showdown, dragging out the proceedings in a way that never feels compelling. While A Fistful of Dollars doesn't measure up to its legacy, it is the first in the trilogy and it's certainly possible that it was a dry run for those later installments that might prove more rewarding.

"A Fistful of Dollars"--Sergio Leone's first entry in the "Dollars" or "Man With No Name" trilogy--begins with an opening title sequence reminiscent of a James Bond opening credit sequence--the stylized cartoonish animation with an exciting boisterous soundtrack (and people getting shot). Not to mention that Leone even references the iconic 'eye' from the Bond sequences. You could even nickname Fistful of Dollars "Western James Bond". It has the trademarks and quirks of a Bond movie, but has it's own uniqueness to it. Sergio has fun modifying the Hollywood clichés known during the movies contemporary time. You think something's going happen, it does, but in a completely different manor than you expected. The plot is as exciting as Ennio Morricone's score. Eastwood's subtle, Max Rockatansky/James Bond/Indiana Jones performance is iconic, yet has it's own quirkiness to it. If only Sergio had a bigger budget than $200,000, the cheap action (e.g. the gun trade where we first see Ramon) would have been much more realistic than a bunch of extras playing Cowboys and Indians.

This is a story of a man who has been in a town, stranded between both gangs and involved badly as things get worse. I love the whole revenge thing. I like stories that involve people, who are very important to the protagonist. And Clint Eastwood is the man, I love him in this film. He is very charismatic as a leading character. He handles that 45 like a boss. And Gian Maria Volonté as Rojo, another bad ass villain. Just watching their facial expressions, it is acting at its best. I love the story, I love the performances, I love the wonderful deserted setting, whether it's day or night, and the ending is one of the most bad ass ending ever in a western. I love the score too. It is a western masterpiece and I can't wait to watch the sequel. 4/5

Kanye West once declared that his presence was a present, but if Kanye West's presence is a present then Clint Eastwood's presence is comparable to that of a new yacht, a smattering of diamonds and gold bars, and a lifetime supply of fried chicken (and if not one of those gifts sounds enticing, then you probably don't exist).  Eastwood is not the kind of actor that smells like a SAG meeting or a thespian conference.  Rather, he possesses enviable tenacity, scowling as if he'd prefer to be angrily smoking on a dimly-lit street corner in Detroit, or somewhere dirtier.  
	When he makes his first appearance in "A Fistful of Dollars," I felt an uncontrollable urge to loudly ask "who is that?", despite being completely aware of his momentous career.  Wearing a weathered cowboy hat, an armor-like poncho, a ten-day beard, and a hardened grimace, he looks considerably iconic.  Eastwood remains nameless for the remainder of the film (most movie buffs refer to him simply as "The Man With No Name"), but he doesn't need a title to define him.  He is a presence.
	"A Fistful of Dollars" familiarized the world with the magnetism of Clint Eastwood, but it also popularized the spaghetti western (one could instead refer to it as the Italian western, but that would be too politically correct), a now much-lampooned sub-genre that slapped the Hollywood western in the face and smacked some sense into its overtly bright and patriotic adventures.  A gaga assembly line of close-ups, uncomfortable silences, sweat, and gunfights, the spaghetti western laughed at Roy Rogers and Randolph Scott hard.  Riding into the sunset or wrangling an unruly horse were now stale, predictable.  The spaghetti western pushed the Old West into the borders of Mexico and made sure to prove that violent sadism can be just as brilliantly conceived as a long-tracking shot in a healthily budgeted Hollywood thriller.
	The Man With No Name is billed as an anti-hero, a gunfighter almost as villainous as the said-villains but ultimately too clever to be marked as a stock rival.  In "A Fistful of Dollars," he finds himself in San Miguel, a tiny border town that is caught in the feud between two powerful families wanting to gain control of the territory.  The Man With No Name sees opportunity among the bitter rivalry; by countering the families against each other, he would thereby receive the monetary benefits of the soon-to-be massacred parties.  
	Truth be told, there are no nice people in "A Fistful of Dollars." They are all so obsessed with furthering their own statuses that any sort of morality has been dead and gone for years, guns and money currently serving as the only forms of life's importance.  Many have rendered the film as being a tepid exercise in arty bloodshed, but that would only be true if it had the same Technicolor innocence as a Roy Rogers or Randolph Scott movie (there those names are again!).  I have always asked myself two questions when it comes to movie violence: (1) Does the violence feel out of place, not matched by the tone of previous scenes? (2) Do you leave the theater so disturbed by the carnage that it serves as the only thing you remember about the film a year later?
	Ultimately, these are probably stupid questions to ask, as they do not directly apply to "A Fistful of Dollars." It creates and lives in its own universe.  You aren't entirely sure what year it takes place in, where San Miguel actually sits, and how these characters became so outrageously handy when it comes to gunplay.  Violence is a part of the equilibrium.  In San Miguel, the kill-or-be-killed philosophy is shown in its truest form.  No pistol parties would be as harmful as banning breathing.
	Sergio Leone is as inventive as Alfred Hitchcock or Steven Spielberg, but because he, along with his films, attract only a small demographic of people, his popularity wanes down to that of a cult filmmaker.  For someone who promoted a new genre and perfected it single-handedly, he deserves much more credit.  As his first hugely influential film, "A Fistful of Dollars" doesn't have the same unbearably tense patience of his spaghetti masterpiece, "Once Upon a Time in West," but it is so outwardly daring that you can still feel the aftershocks of the groundbreaking waves it made back in 1964.  His style has been imitated time and time again, but still intact is that original underlying feeling that no one has done this before.  It is a provocative and flashy work that walks alone on a dusty path in the desert of cinema.  
	With its flaws in mind, saying Leone was finding his footing wouldn't be entirely accurate.  In "A Fistful of Dollars," you see him trying something unheard of with much luster, and it's immediately apparent that a snowball effect will ensue: The more movies Leone makes, the better they will get.  Though he only directed a total of seven, they all contain enough personality to bolster the projects of director who has made hundreds of movies.  "A Fistful of Dollars" is certainly one of them.

A Fistful of Dollars is a story about a small Western town that is being terrorized by 2 gangs. Then a quiet stranger wanders into town, and he manages to pit these 2 organizations against one another in hopes that he can profit from it. The most interesting aspect of this film was that Clint Eastwood did not play a traditional white-hat type of character. He wasn't particularly altruistic, he just wanted a paycheck. That actually gave his character some depth, and kept me guessing as to when he would reach a breaking point and decide that a job was going a bit too far for him. The biggest issue I had with the film was the audio. Apparently the actors were all talking in multiple different languages and they just dubbed in all the lines. Even Eastwood, who is speaking English, doesn't totally line up his lips to the words so it's clear they used ADR for him too. It is an awkward experience watching the unsynched dialogue, and I think some of the acting performances suffer because I'm not even sure they are actually saying the words that are being put in their mouth. That's the biggest hurdle to enjoying A Fistful of Dollars. Once I got past that, it was a very good film.

There are 2 things I think we all can admit that Sergio Leone is the master of in his spaghetti-westerns. First of all the music. It has this unique style that mixes a number of sounds you don't often find in film scores, which have now become synonymous with Westerns. It just fits so perfectly and it is used brilliantly throughout the film. But the bigger one is the fact that Sergio Leone is the master of the stand-off. That final sequence where Eastwood comes face-to-face with his enemies is so intense. Even though it had been spoiled for me by Back to the Future 2, there were still some surprising moments in the end. That is the kind of satisfying conclusion that the audience craves. We see the anti-hero going mano-a-mano against the villian and only one of them will be able to walk away. That whole sequence alone is probably better than most action movies I've seen this year. The movie did drag at a few points getting there, but once you hit that moment it's all been worth the wait. I can't wait to explore the other movies in Leone's Man-With-No-Name Trilogy, because I imagine he only got better. For Western fans A Fistful of Dollars is a must-see.
Absolute classic Clint Eastwood.
Solid first movie of the dollars trilogy. Clint Eastwood plays the famed man with no name very well, and the last half of the movie is really, really good.

Sergio Leone's creates the pessimistic and desolate world of the spaghetti westerns with this flick, where  the characters are trapped in a world of constant conflict and death, where you can only get by being subordinate to those who have the gun and power or being a wisecrack like our main protagonist here.

The landscapes shots are panoramic and great, which will eventually become his signature style, but at the same time it reminding us this was always a terrible place to settle anyway being in the middle of a scorching desert. The juxtaposition of the town in the landscape makes for a very dismal and miserable place where there exists no prosperity or joy for the residents but the constant reminder of death and brutality at the hands of those who control power. Thus one resides to being docile and making the care necessities of life the priority.

Along comes the cynical rogue gunslinger who'd do anything to get rich even going to the point of inciting a war between two rivaling factions. He has adapted himself to the this tough world and has mastered the trades to flourish within it. He's apathetic but his actions reveals that he once had a good human heart. Clint Eastwood plays the character with roughness akin to a razor blade scraping a rock. He's never deterred and his own rules and conviction which inadvertently causes a chain of events that results in a bloody massacre. He's not someone who we root for, because his motives are unclear and always has a sinister, in addition to a indifferent, connotation.

The film is anything but triumphant, because in the end the actions of the protagonist never changes the direction of the cruel world he inhabits but he merely exists to propagate it. Although whenever he sees a glimpse of real human feeling of love trickling through the hard layer of misery and despair, he knows it's a rare thing and he does everything to make it escape before it vanishes. He cannot feel love, because his heart's gone too cold and he cannot change the grim world because that's the only place where he knows how to live. He just straddles along in his horse waiting for his next fix of violence and gold.
Plot is about as thick as any other western - not at all! A good one to get you ready for the infamous The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly though.
Nice performances by Eastwood and Volonté, but it is clear that Leone's style is unripe.

As beautiful as it is, I can't shake the feeling of watching a blatant Yojimbo ripoff from my head. The true fascinating entertainment comes from the observation how Leone adapted a samurai story and its visual and cultural elements into a genuine classic western.
Clint Eastwood is one badass mofo and it makes for an awesome western flick. Morricone's unique music sets the tone so well.

A landmark Western and first of Sergio Leone's Spaghetti Trilogy, it also follows The Magnificent Seven as an excellent example of a plot from a Kurosawa samurai movie crossing over into the western genre, this time with 1961's Yojimbo.
Clint Eastwood is The Man With No Name, a drifter who rides into a small Mexican town where two rival gangs are embroiled in a power struggle. Eastwood makes himself a mercenary for hire, first to the Mexican family, The Rojo's, who control the town's liquor, but then switches to the other side, The Baxter's, who control the town's firearms.
Eastwood is superb as the mystery man with little to no honour or morality, a man who can speak entire sentences without having any dialogue through his facial expressions alone.
Though A Fistful Of Dollars is nowhere near as good as The Good, The Bad & The Ugly, it does make a great first installment to a classic trilogy of films.

I sure do miss when films were this amazing. Westerns were the big sellers back then and this film clearly shows why the genre lasted for so long. The idea of a western film can be easy to do on paper, but delivery and direction is the most important part of any movie. A Fistful of Dollars perfectly captures the western feel while having a great atmosphere of the dark and grittiness. This is when the grit was actually good and had things to back it up as these were the times bodies dropped like flies. Clint Eastwood as the unknown traveling cowboy is one of the best characters in the genre because of how much he does. The man sees that there is a town in danger because of a power struggle between two groups as the government cannot do anything as even they get slaughtered by the rouges. The film also explores into a nice sense of humor at little bits that really gets you to feel how everyone feels, again creating the western atmosphere correctly. I even love how the overall set up for this film works out, it makes you wonder what is going to happen. There are many scenes that make you wonder what is happening and seeing things end one at a time easily fulfills the plot with a great pace. The best part to a good build up though is the suspense and when things start firing it keeps getting more and more suspenseful. A masterful film, and even saying that doesn't fully honor A Fistful of Dollars. It easily stands up to the test of time and easily keeps Clint Eastwood as the western icon.
A Fistful of Dollars begins a trilogy of western classics, with an undeniably top-notch performance from Clint Eastwood, a clever and interesting story, and of course Ennio Morricone's iconic score.
Clint Eastwood's acting and Sergio Leone's directing was a magical combination from the beginning.

A western classic that's typically really good and heightens Eastwood's acting career by his fine performance. (B+)

A solid debut from now acclaimed director Sergio Leone, but Kurosawa's Yojimbo (the movie that inspired it) is much better.

Undeniably iconic but arguably thinner than Kurosawa's grey-moral landmark about justice and sacrifice. In the end, A Fistful of Dollars achieves grandeur but in expense of conflict and depth that made Yojimbo a classic.

While "A Fistful of Dollars" is a seminal film that changed an entire genre, I find it far more dated than later Eastwood westerns. Some sweeping vistas and good acting can't make up for some terribly cheesy action scenes and awkward writing.

A Fistful of Dollars is a western classic and one that helped cement
the westerns of the 50's and 60's in the memories of fans and new
audiences alike. With a smartly written, acted and directed story you
can't help but watch this and enjoy it and take in the sights of this
wonderfully set movie. I enjoyed all of it and for those who enjoy
westerns I couldn't recommend this more as a piece. I felt it was a an
Excellent and Great film and below is why I felt that about it, and so
many other people did too.

The story as I say is smart and well thought out, and with some great
characters and parallel families, it just makes for one big and fun
western, oh and with some bloody violence too. I guess to say this is
fun is the wrong word and although it is hugely enjoyable the story is
dark and makes for drama at some points, but then goes into some good
old gun shoot outs(including the old extremely loud gunshots we got in
classic western films). Finally we get a character who guides us
through a slow plot but he does it so well it seems even faster.

Clint Eastwood in the main role without a name is superb and his
menacing voice coupled with his great performance makes for an
interesting acting role indeed. I loved the supporting cast and even
though no one stands out anywhere near Eastwood, they still do a great
job and do what all supporting casts should do even today in film.
Finally on the acting it is strong, for some films like this they don't
all do well but in this you feel everyone does what there meant to do
all the way through.

Director Sergio Leone does his job here every well and if it wasn't for
the other films in the Man With No Name series then this would be his
finest by far. He also had a hand in writing this as well and with a
massive writing team we got a great script that when put together with
the film is just superb. I liked the chase scenes, gun scenes and
anything in the beautiful landscape and for when this was made the
quality of the stunts and deaths are great and they don't seem cheesy
at all which can happen so often in films of this era.

I felt criticism wise that although it warrants very very little, the
story could be seen as over dramatic and too much cheesy lines and
violence that doesn't fit in with the more quiet scenes. I don't feel
they affected it and weren't cheesy etc but that is what could be said
about the film. As I have said before I think you have to form your own
opinion if you like it or not as I couldn't really find much to
criticise this about really.

I would Recommend this to those who enjoy a good western film or those
who like a good bit of action but it also being drama and tense moments
where a shoot-out could happen any second. I believe many will enjoy
this as the story is thick with smartly written lines and I said about
the tense shoot-outs, well they are every tense and in a sense you
could describe this film as a thriller film because sometimes your
heart can beat faster when the more quiet stand off's are around.

Overall I give it a high 8/10 and it is a Great and Excellent film and a firm
one of that. I think some will like this film even more than I do,
where as some I believe will dislike it, but the only way to find out
is to watch it, because the film is classic cinema using one of if not
the most famous western star of all time in Clint Eastwood. Finally I
will say this is a must for all cinema lovers as it is truly a cinema
classic and to say this is in the series that includes "The Good The
Bad And The Ugly" it really is a great series of films, just excellent.

Last night, I got a chance to see the classic 1964 spaghetti western, A Fistful of Dollars on the big screen for the very first time. The film starred a young Clint Eastwood as a cynical gunfighter with no name who comes to a small border town & offers his services to two rival gangs. The two gangs are unaware that the mysterious figure is playing both sides. Famous Italian director Sergio Leono who also co-wrote the screenplay with Victor Andres Catena & Jaime Comas crafted a spectacularly entertaining, & wryly funny first chapter of the famous " Man With No Name " trilogy which includes itâ??s 1965 follow-up, For a Few Dollars More & the iconic 1966 film, The Good, the Bad, & the Ugly . The performances from this small cast were excellent. The action scenes were intense, shockingly violent & heart-pounding. The look of the film was stunning from the landscape of the desert to the small town. The music in the film was fantastic especially  during the back & forth close-ups on their faces during the big showdown at the end of the film. For those who havenâ??t seen this film, I HIGHLY recommend seeing it to appreciate the old time movie making.
The original spaghetti western-- the acting  is still a bit wooden, but the music, the realism and grimyness must have been a shock to the original audiences.

A Fistful of Dollars has classic Sergio Leone direction and a witty script, but lacks everything else needed to be an exceptional western. As a result, A Fistful of Dollars is far inferior to the classic The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly

A Fistful Of Dollars is the first of the Sergio Leone Spaghetti Westerns I am going to watch, since as a big Clint Eastwood fan, I feel ashamed to say I haven't lost myself in the 'Dollars' trilogy just yet. It's the first in the series, and as much as I haven't gotten into the series till now, A Fistful of Dollars makes it challenging for me to watch A Few Dollars More, because this regarded 'classic' didn't necessarily blow me away. It's a solid western, featuring Clint (never fails), but as I have heard, lays the template for the next films where Leone really begins to take his form as an epic storyteller.

Clint Eastwood is the man with no name, who decides to stay around a bad town, where the only money that comes through is for booze and guns. It's small town, run by two gangs, the Baxters and the Rohos. When a small town like this one has two bosses, it never goes well. The Man is warned to leave unless he wants to be shot dead, but he sees a fair opportunity to make a few dollars. He approaches both gangs offering his work, but not for cheap. Both gangs get interested in him, and let him help with their objective. What both groups don't know, is that The Man is playing both sides, trying to take advantage of everyone for his gain. Everybody's packin' heat, but The Man is confident he'll come away with the last laugh.

It is an iconic movie, but I feel like it is the stepping stone in this series. It's a legendary series, one of the biggest in cinematic history, but 'A Fistful' kind of feels like a bit of a prologue to what could possibly be two much more enthralling entries. I haven't seen the other two, but from what I've heard from some people, is that the whole thing really picks up with a Few Dollars More and The Good, The Bad, The Ugly. That being said, it isn't necessarily a bad thing. I like to think that great series are built like this. A first movie that doesn't really wow, but leaves room for it later. There are a lot of series where the original movie can blow you away, but leaves nothing for the sequels that come off as lackluster. I feel it's the exact opposite here, where the trilogy will only get more entertaining with each passage. Still, A Fistful of Dollars is an entertaining movie.

A couple things bothered me. One, it may have been a bit too short. If we saw a little bit more interaction between Clint and the two gangs, showing his fake dedication and watching it grow, only to come down to an even greater finale, I think that would have worked well. Maybe this isn't the case, but I still think that the finale here is a great one. The movie really does slow sometimes, but it's a couple of different iconic scenes in here that make the whole movie a bit more badass. Clint Eastwood is badass per usual, but not really as much as I'm used to. It was like a reserved badassery, but maybe that's the nature of his character. When it comes to cons, the acting is pretty B-Level (not surprising to me really), and the dubs for some of the characters (who I presume are speaking italian) are pretty shotty. It's still a solid western, that has atleast captured some of my interest to check out the next one.

A Fistful of Dollars acts as a stepping stone for the rest of the 'Dollars Trilogy'. While expecting more, it's still a solid spaghetti western with some memorable scenes.
Not that great of a movie, overrated..

Good movie. Not as compelling as  Once Upon a Time in ghe West, but easier to follow than The Good, The Bad and the Ugly. I have to say it has worst fake movie blood I have ever seen...almost bright orange.

it's a western with just enough action to make it  interesting & worthy

I wish now I had watched Yojimbo.  If this movie is just the homage, Yojimbo must be amazing, because this was totally badass.  I'm not big into old Westerns, so I don't have a lot of experience in saying what's a good Western and what's not, but I can confidently say this movie, really the entire trilogy, should be watched at least once.  
Eastwood is so smooth as the gunfighter, so charismatic, it's easy to see how the character is one of Hollywood's most recognizable icons.  He is the alpha definition of the lone good guy anti-hero from which other great characters, including Han Solo, were born.
The plot is such a recognizable plot now.  Skilled fighter breezes into a town ruled by feuding gangs, then plays the system where the gangs devour themselves while he walks away a little richer (in spirit?).  It's almost like this is how Romeo & Juliet should play out instead of the way it did.  And since the plot is borrowed from Yojimbo, it bears noting again the genius of Akria Kurosawa who directed that and Seven Samurai.  The stories are masterpieces.  They're so easy and simple to comprehend, and lend themselves to nearly any time and situation, much like many of Shakespeare's plays.  It takes a genius to create a template for a tale that speaks to a basic, understood element of the human condition.  In this case, the nature of the hero, even one who doesn't want to seem comfortable with the role.
Classic cool.   One of the few movies I can watch more than one time.

A satisfying plate of spaghetti western filled with some real nasty bad guys and a fantastic musical score. The movie plays as you'd expect and entertains throughout leading to a great ending. Well worth tracking down.

Sergio Leone's Spaghetti Westerns are my transition to Western films in general. They were the first Western films that I truly appreciated. After Leone's trilogy, this led me to other western films like The Magnificent Seven and 3:10 To Yuma. A Fistful of Dollars was the first of the trilogy and in my opinion is the weakest out of the three.

The film was written by a couple of writers, one of which includes Sergio Leone. This is the area of the film that I felt was the weakest as simple the plot may be, it lacks a strong build up to the memorable and exciting climax. The characters aren't as interesting in this film in comparison to the subsequent films, an example of poorly written characters in this film are The Baxters. They feel two dimensional and plain. I did enjoy the banter between Clint Eastwood and Jose Calvo. The dialogue in this film feels a lot more cheesier than the other films, most of it is good but there are moments that feels cringe-worthy. It is definitely a big risk in creating a protagonist with no background, it can be hard to empathise with but at the same time it allows the audience to become curious of the character and allows him to become unpredictable. The film's plot showcases the protagonist's greed and it's aftermath.

The film's biggest strength is Leone's direction. Leone wanted to create something different from other westerns and focused on building tension between events making it much more effective. Leone has created something patient and at times quiet, in particular the first few minutes of the film. The film is definitely limited by it's budget, with the setting feeling plain and lifeless.

Massimo Dallamano is the cinematographer of this film, and also for the next film. Dallamano and Leone has focused on using close ups and at times they are extreme. These shots are commonly found on iconic moments of the film, like the climax or the switch in the middle of the film. The film's overall look feels much more grittier, this may be due to budget constraints or the filmmakers are not as confident with their shots in comparison to the subsequent films. There is a particular scene, which I thought was beautifully done and the scene was the first time we see Eastwood uses his gun, having the camera placed low and shooting it on the point of view of the gun.

One of the most memorable aspect of this film is the score. Ennio Morricone has created something that sticks with you and have you thinking of his score when you ever think of a Western situation. The beautiful sound of the guitar as it plays Eastwood out and that whistle that sticks with you throughout the film. The score is definitely influenced from the previous released Western films in that era but makes it his own. The score doesn't try to sound complicated or innovative but rather stripping it down, which fits the protagonist of the film.

Eastwood definitely stands out in this film, as his character and his portrayal of it is the main reason people are so hooked to this film. Eastwood has created a character that makes the audience wonder and at times idolise as he never seems to get corrupted by the cliche things found in Westerns, aside from money of course. The other stand out in this film is Gian Maria Volonte playing the film's antagonist and Jose Calvo as Silvanito. Volonte creates a villain that doesn't feel over the top and times look really cool and slick, while Calvo plays as the comic relief supported by the banter between him and Eastwood.

This film may not be perfect in my eyes, while other praise it. It definitely is an important film for me as it introduced me to a genre of film that I never thought I would appreciate. A Fistful of Dollars sets up the style and genre that is found on Leone's next few films.
when a man with a .45 meets a man with rifle...
Leone's filmmaking, Eastwood's performance, and Morricone's score are all a bit raw and undisciplined in this first teaming, but all the elements of greatness are evident, just waiting to be refined.

Pretty good film right here. I loved Clint Eastwood's performance and he really killed it here for sure. In addition, the cinematography was top-notch and the setting/decor was also really well done and really fit the "Western" theme extremely well. Another positive here was definitely the action sequences as well as the build-up of the conflict. Both really hooked you in and left you wanting more, while providing thrill after thrill.

Despite those positives, there are some definite negatives. One of the biggest ones would be the shootouts actually, as when somebody gets shot, it looks extremely fake. Now, watching this in 2014 and comparing it to films of today is unfair, but regardless, even with the 1960's technology available to them, I really wish that he at least looked somewhat realistic and not just completely acted. Another would be the dubbing. For when this film came out, it is impressive, but at times, it was painfully noticeable and really hampered my enjoyment of the film. 

However, aside from these two things, I really enjoyed this one. It is a great way to kick off the "Man With No Name" trilogy and serves as a strong introduction to Clint Eastwood's character and, really, Sergio Leone's style.
It's Leone's satisfyingly simple mix of guns, cigars, action, and Clint Eastwood that makes a spaghetti western classic, as well as reinvent the genre.
Filmed beautifully with assuredly cool cinematic flair, Sergio Leone's seminal Western is a breath-taking masterpiece of iconic stylishness and hard hitting violence.

This movie features a lone man coming into a town of two families that's always bordering the edge of full-scale gunfighting.  He double-crosses both families, and works for his own cause.  Sound classic?  That's because it is.  It's the godfather of Spaghetti Westerns, and one of my favorite films of all time.
Everyone should see this trilogy. Required viewing. Sublime

Stealing only from the best of cinema, both Western and Eastern, director Sergio Leone and actor Clint Eastwood debut strongly in A Fistful of Dollars, a low-budget film in the Wild West centered on a drifter (Eastwood) caught in a feud between two rival gangs in a town held hostage. Some tropes have not stood the test of time too well (ex. Damn the pride of a ruthless killer, foregoing strategy for principles), others have stood well (ex. Every action sequence, most prominently the now classic "showdown" stance... though Leone would soon perfect this in later movies). Add some refreshing twists, like the complete absence of exposition for Eastwood's character, and you have a pretty good Western action flick.
A textbook model for the spaghetti western, A Fistful of Dollars is a fantastic movie that benefits greatly from Clint Eastwood's stern performance and director Sergio Leone's masterful touch.
My favorite out of the dollars trilogy
