Sergio Leone created a hell of a spaghetti western that is a masterpiece to its genre.
Clint Eastwood gives a memorable performance along with the rest of the ethnic cast.
Plus, Ennio Morricone composed the best and most fitting score for the soundtrack, he is a master.
Great spaghetti western flick.

Leone's first western certainly isn't his most ambitious. However, the familiar, simple take it has on the anonymous-man-coming-to-town-and-helping-the-good-guys story is so wonderfully told with the director's unique touches of style and unflinching propensity for violence. The action is fun, intense and exciting, and the bad guys are presented so that hating them is an absolute joy. Gritty and engrossing.

I really enjoyed the lawless setting of the US / Mexican border. These Clint Eastwood Spaghetti Westerns are the oldest westerns I can watch. I don't have any nostalgia for old westerns and can't take the bad acting, bad dialog, and cheap western town scenery.
One of the few old westerns I can watch and enjoy.
Not quite on the level of the movie that "inspired" it, but still a superior western and a career-maker for Eastwood.
Brilliant film. If you don't like this film, then you don't know true westerns.
One of my favorites of all time!!!

My reviews of the entire Dollars Trilogy is here and what better way to start off, but with the beginning of the trilogy? Here is my review of "A Fistful of Dollars. The story is about "Joe" or simply, the Man with No Name, as he takes on a war in a forgotten little town that is run by death and misery. It is up to "Joe" to end this war and bring peace and happiness to the town as it once was. I can't express my happiness of how this film turned out. It has been MANY years since its release and still stands out. The performances are just stunning especially from the legendary, Clint Eastwood, who delivers a badass mysterious bounty hunter/killer. The movie IS pretty long, but that didn't stop me from having fun with this movie. Seriously, this movie is THAT old and yet it never kept me bored. The gun battles are well done and the setting is just perfect. The final fight scene is probably the most badass and most recognizable scenes to date. Having Back to the Future parody this scene and yet it is still pretty badass. No matter how old this film is, it still holds very well and it gave one iconic actor his most iconic role yet. I got nothing else to say about A Fistful, but it is just a pure badass western..........go see it.

A Fistful of Dollars is a genius film for its time and for all of movie history. Clint Eastwood, though the only real relevant actor in the film, carries the show on his shoulders to complete perfection, which is part of what makes him one of the greatest actors of all time. If you took the fragments of this film solely capturing his journey into the Mexican village full of violent murders capped off with facing the vicious Ramon, it would be enough on its own to make its own movie. And it would still be fantastic enough to be the classic that it is.

The film that made the spaghetti westerns a household name and gave rise to one of the most iconic western stars, Fistful of Dollars is a  near beautiful masterpiece.  What puts it near the top of all westerns is easily the story.  In just under an hour and forty-five minutes, Sergio Leone puts great work into turning a classic samurai film into a classic western with the twists and iconic moments kept intact.  Eastwood is perfect as The Man with No Name and his counterparts do a near perfect job at keeping up.  For 1964 Leone takes a bold direction with a western that clearly pays off in a big way.

While film is technically a remake, it still holds up extremely well and is a great example of what makes a good western.

While not as good as the third entry, still a great movie. Eastwood is fantastic as the infamous Man with No Name. The shootouts were extremely entertaining, and the finale was great. A great movie overall.

A very good movie, my favorite of the Dollars Trilogy.  This movie would not have been made if not for Yojimbo and probably should not be rated higher on the tomatometer (just sayin) but it is great in its own right nonetheless.  The 'apologize to my mule' scene is one of my favorites.  Eastwood is something else on screen and this may be his best role.

Yes, Leone directed it and Eastwood is in it, but did I like it, well no. I'm not a huge western fan to begin with, and the storytelling dearth of A Fistful of Dollars threw me off. Now, when you look at its historical importance and meaning it's evident that the film's value cannot be undermined. I just didn't enjoy it very much, it's not my cup of tea. And that's well basically it. The Leone frame is rich in drama and composition, the epic nature of the frontier as accentuated beautifully. It's just not for me. Recommended, if for nothing else, to see a collaboration of two masters of cinema.

A fairly bleak, visually striking film that uses the small, conflict ravaged town it's set in to great effect. Eastwood plays an interesting if sparsely written hero, someone manipulative and self-serving while still having enough of a moral compass to put himself at risk over innocents.

This is obviously a classic western which portrays many stereotypical western movie situations that you may or may not have seen done as a parody in recent years.  The quality of the film making and of the acting performance by a young Clint Eastwood astonished me, especially for a 49 year old film.  Frankly, I love this movie, and from what people tell me, it is the least successful of the trilogy.  Obviously... I can't wait to watch the next one.

Had a mini-marathon of the first two films of Sergio Leone's Dollars trilogy that I still haven't seen a.k.a. films I should have seen by now. The first one is a Western remake of Akira Kurosawa's "Yojimbo" and pretty much follows the same plot. It's my least favorite of the trilogy but that's not to say it isn't a pretty great film. It takes a while to get going and could have used a bit more of the black humor of the original but when it gets going, it never lets up. Extra points for the great Ennio Morricone score.
A Fistful of Dollars, the first entry in Sergio Leone's epic dollars trilogy, is an outstanding western with a well written story and mesmerizing performances!

A perfect remake of a perfect film. A Fistful of Dollars may not quite be as good as Kurosawa's Yojimbo, but it's way more fun. Clint Eastwood, while not Leone's first choice to play "Joe", he's definitely the only guy who could match Toshiro Mifune's quiet, cool and intelligent loner. It is the film that created a genre and for good reason, it oozes cool and has style in spades. Leone's unique style on A Fistful of Dollars has become iconic, and for good reason. It's extreme closeups weren't something seen in westerns often, especially American westerns. The fantastic and quick editing gives it that style I talked about. Then there is Ennio Morricone's score that is also iconic and was so influential. The main theme will get stuck in your head for days. Everything about this movie is a classic. Guess what it only gets better with these three icons of cinema with their next two Dollars/Man With No Name movies.
A good movie for its time, but it definitely shows its age. The lip syncing is some of the worst I've ever seen.
a great realistic and gritty take on the modern Western. Plus a great character development by Clint Eastwood.

One of Sergio Leone's great masterpieces and one of the greatest films in the world. Clint Eastwood plays the role perfectly and Ennio Morricone's great music in the background make this film even more enjoyable to watch.
Fantastic film. Sometimes it was hard to realize what was going on, but overall one of my favorites.

Inspired by the Kurosawa classic "Yojimbo," "Fistful" is compact and simple compared to the epic "The Good, The Bad and The Ugly," but has its fair share of moments.  After years of outdoor shooting on "Rawhide," the sensitivity of Eastwood's eyes culminates in the epic presentation of his trademark squint, a coping mechanism for the bright Spanish sun.  He keeps it cool though, the coolest yet.  Like Leone's other works, the film has plenty of style with an epic and violent tone.  The visual quality is good and the audio is post synchronized, which presents the same issues as it did in the 1966 finale/prequel.  Ennio Morricone's score is beautiful, yet an order of magnitude smaller than his work on "TGTBaTU" or "Once Upon a Time in the West."  I would say that the moments of greatness manage to justify the plethora of similar films that would follow.  (5 April 2013)
The lesser of the three films. They get progressively better.
Classic spaghetti western

Two things a western must have: an ever more intriguing storyline, tied with an utterly bad-ass character (in this case Clint Eastwood unforgettably dressed in his poncho, with a cigar poking out his mouth). Both are more than covered in this film, while adding a brilliant village and utterly perfect soundtrack. A godly manifestation of a western.
As I imagined, western is not for me. Though it's clear Tarantino is a fan

The one that started it all! The film that introduced America to a true cinematic hero (Eastwood) and the film making world to a genius of a director (Leone). If you like westerns, it's a must. This one has a lot of good, violent bloody shootouts, it's an absolute blast!
My favorite Eastwood western with a solid yet simple story with intelligent dialog and just enough action to keep it interesting.
Great spaghetti western, more to the serious side but funny.

The one that started it all. A wandering gunfighter plays with two rival families whose hatred has torn apart a whole town. While the story may have been lifted off Kurosawa's film 'Yojimbo', a Fistful of Dollars is the unique stylised vision of a legendary filmmaker in his own right Sergio Leone, who revolutionised the western genre and kickstarted the influential celebrated cinematic movement now known as the spaghetti western. Brimming with visual creativity that is instantly iconic, starring an iconic Clint Eastwood and a crazed Volonté, with a pacing dictated by the wonderful score by Ennio Morricone, this film is simply wonderful and nothing short of age defining.
This is such an essential film because of it's influence of the latter two films in the trilogy. The film itself is so stylish in it's visuals and script, that looking away seems impossible.

To be honest, I found it pretty crude and boring. It's a first movie, and quickly eclipsed by its sequels. There are glimmers of genius, mostly a collection of beautiful, evocative close-up shots, and the general air of malevolence and nihilism.

A great start for many people in this film from Clint Eastwood about to start his journey as one of the most influential actor out there. The ground breaking music from Ennio Morricone, the great western director Sergio Leone. But its a more then great start for the truly amazing film trilogy "The Dollars trilogy".
Fistful Of Dollars takes elements of Akira Kurosawa's Yojimbo and makes them its own. Clint Eastwood as the man with no name is truly cinemas first one liner badass.

An isolated town in Western America where the emphasis on death seems an ordinary seems an ordinary thing in this town. A lone ranger plans on cleaning this town up.
This film is so amazing because of the protagonist 'the man with no name'. He says very little wasn't afraid to use violence to proove his point. it's because he says very little what makes him mystique. He is one of the greatest characters i have ever seen along with 'the godfather'.
The film itself is an amazing watch it rejuvantes the western genre, Joe wearing the Poncho with his cigar and squinting eyes and rugged beard and an amazing confidence which i admire.
The score is very recognisable and works so well, they use it awful lot but it makes the character seem more powerful.
One of my favourite parts of the film is when Joe walks upto the four cowboys who think they can mock anyone. Joe with his head tilted downwards lifts his hat up and asks them to apologize very calmly and shoots all four of them so quickly and this is when i see his true power.
The film is directed by Sergio Leone and the film was known as a spaghetti western made in Italy and differed from the classic western with cowboys and Indians this one involves the mexican Outlaws and A lone ranger. Although some cliches exsit with a typical damsel in distress and the guns and clothing. Theres also typical stereotypes including the bad guys being bad, the towns people remain scared and hidden.
Joe is like a middle man in this film, he intends on flushing out the bad guys out, like most westerns the woman in distress is saved by Joe valiantly.
Joe really does walkaway with 'a fistful of Dollars' by tricking the good guys and the bad but has to endure torture and little blood on his hands.
Clints persona in this film carried on during his time as an actor and is such a true actor and makes me jelous of his presence.
Cinemotagraphy the film uses cliched super zoom shots showing emotion, Joes squinting eyes is enough to disturb any man. Long shots and for for the shoot showing shadows of the midday sun is nothing new but Sergio films has some of the actors flaws which show the film was set in europe. With some actors voices being pretty poor as they are italians playing mexicans can be spotted especially the little boy when he cries 'mama'.
Overall the film is an amazingly crafted film flourishing the talents of Clint Eastwood and is worth the watch.

Starring Clint Eastwood with director Sergio Leone, this western adaption of Yojimbo has a poncho-wearing gunslinger (Eastwood) playing to rival gangs off of each other. Upon entering the town, the man with no name is soon disturbed by the Baxters and he makes light work of four men. Then, he decides to join the rival Rojos gang while spending the rest of his time at the local saloon. After a massacre takes place over some gold, the man uses two of the bodies to lure both sides out to a cemetery  In the ensuing chaos, the Rojos capture one man and then the man with no name sends a hostage over the the Baxters. He was able to get money from both sides before the exchange took place. That night the Rojos celebrate and the gunslinger sneaks off to rescue a woman who is captive. He does a virtuous deed but is found out and the Rojos beat him to a pulp. Using his ingenuity yet again, the man escapes to fight another day. Thinking he received help from the Baxters, the Rojos brutally wipe them out. With his friend the innkeeper in trouble, the man returns for the final showdown. He outwits his foe and beats the sharpshooter, Ramon, at his own game. As would become the norm  the man would ride off as the victor in one of Leone's famous panoramic shots.

A great start to a great trilogy, Clint Eastwood begins his iconic "The Man With No Name" character superbly. Very clever and entertaining, well paced, and stylish, this film redefined the western genre and created an iconic character that would change film making forever. You just can't get any cooler than Clint Eastwood, and he does what he does best here.

The first of the brilliant 'spaghetti western' films. Clint Eastwood stars as his cool 'The Man with No Name' role, it's hard to imagine somebody else in the role. Ennio Morricone's score is remarkable.
It may not register as a big hit in effects, but the early signs of great story teling put this one down in the history books
This clever classic grabs you're attention  with it's interesting yet mysterious scenario and has you on the edge of your seat until the very end.
